'''Karl Wilhelm von Feuerbach''' (30 May 1800 – 12 March 1834) was a German [[geometer]] and the son of legal scholar [[Paul Johann Anselm Ritter von Feuerbach]], and the brother of philosopher [[Ludwig Feuerbach]]. After receiving his doctorate at age 22, he became a professor of [[mathematics]] at the [[Gymnasium (school)|Gymnasium]] at [[Erlangen]]. In 1822 he wrote a small book on mathematics noted mainly for a theorem on the [[nine-point circle]], which is now known as [[Feuerbach's theorem]]. In 1827 he introduced [[homogeneous coordinates]], independently of [[August Ferdinand Möbius|Möbius]].<ref>[http://sfabel.tripod.com/mathematik/database/Feuerbach.html M20 Mathematik LK Facharbeit: Karl Wilhelm Feuerbach]</ref>
